questions.text: Identify the bullet range.
questions.solution: When a gunshot wound shows blackening and tattooing around it, this indicates a close range shot. Blackening is caused by the deposition of soot and gunpowder residue from the burning propellant, while tattooing is due to the impact of unburned powder particles. These signs are typically seen when the muzzle is relatively close to the target, usually within a few feet.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with weight loss, numbness in his hands and feet, and hyperpigmented spots on his palms. Examination reveals transverse white lines across his fingernails. He has a history of chronic exposure to pesticides. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Aldrich Mees lines (white lines across the nails) and raindrop pigmentation (small, round pigmented spots on the skin, particularly on the palms) are classic signs of arsenic poisoning.

Thallium (Option B): Thallium poisoning typically causes symptoms such as alopecia (hair loss), gastrointestinal distress, and peripheral neuropathy. While it can affect the skin and nails, it does not characteristically cause Aldrich Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation.

Cadmium (Option C): Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and bones, leading to renal tubular dysfunction and bone demineralization. It does not cause Aldrich Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation.

Lead (Option D): Lead poisoning can lead to a variety of symptoms, including abdominal pain, encephalopathy, and a characteristic blue line on the gums (Burton's line). However, it does not cause Aldrich Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.solution:
Adipocere is a waxy substance formed postmortem due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of fat tissues in the body. This process is called saponification.

Adipocere (Saponification or Grave Wax):

  • Formation of fatty acid soap in warm, humid climates or when submerged in water. (Option B, C ruled out)
  • Process: Fatty acids undergo hydrolysis and hydrogenation, forming a waxy substance.
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Preserves body tissues for easier identification.
    • Formation takes 3 days to 3 months. (Option D ruled out)
  • Types of adipocere:
    • Fresh: Soft, moist, white, greasy.
    • Old: Dry, hard, brittle, yellow.
  • Absent fetus less than 7 months.

Learning Objective:

Mummification

  • Occurs in dry, hot climates due to dehydration, preserving the body.
  • Loss of 60-70% body weight over 3-12 months.
  • Intra-uterine death can also result in mummification.
  • Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favors the process of mummification
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Helps in the determination of time since death (TSD) and easy identification.

questions.text: In a medicolegal examination, an accused 18-year-old male claims he is 16 years old. Which joint X-ray should be done to determine his age?
questions.solution:
The distal femur and proximal tibia (knee) and the distal radius and ulna (wrist) are commonly used for age estimation in late adolescence. The fusion of the epiphyses in these joints typically completes around 18-19 years, making them ideal for distinguishing between 16 and 18 years of age.

Head & shoulder (Option A): The head and shoulder are not commonly used for age estimation in this age group because the epiphyseal fusion in these regions occurs earlier and may not provide reliable evidence for distinguishing between 16 and 18 years of age.

Elbow and ankle (Option B): The elbow is useful for younger individuals, as the epiphyseal fusion in this area is typically complete by 16 years. The ankle is also not a standard site for differentiating ages in late adolescence.

Elbow & hip (Option D): While the elbow is used for age estimation in younger individuals, the hip is not typically used for this purpose in the 16-18 age range due to earlier fusion.

questions.text: The dead body shows characteristic findings (as depicted in the image). What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Smothering involves obstruction of the nose and mouth, usually without specific injuries to the neck. Bruises or abrasions on the face may be present but are not localized to the neck.

Hanging (Option A): Hanging typically shows an oblique, non-continuous ligature mark on the neck, located higher up (above the thyroid cartilage). There is usually no evidence of external injuries like bruises or fingernail marks around the neck.

Throttling (Option B): Throttling refers to manual strangulation. The findings often include bruising, abrasions, or fingernail marks on the neck, which are characteristic of a physical struggle. There may also be petechial hemorrhages in the eyes and other areas due to venous congestion.

questions.text: A child was born 8 months after the father's death. The grandparents questioned the paternity, but DNA confirmed the child belongs to their son. What is this child called?
questions.solution:
A posthumous child is one born after the death of the father. The scenario described fits this definition

Suppositious child (Option A):

  • This term describes a fictitious child where a woman maypretend to be pregnant and later present a living child as her own.
  • This can involve substituting one child for another or claiming a child after an abortion, typically for financial gain or to claim property.
  • In this case, there is no indication of deception or substitution, so this option does not apply.

Fabricated child (Option B):

Fabricated or induced illness (FII) is an uncommon type of child abuse where a parent or caregiver intentionally exaggerates or causes symptoms of illness in a child.

Illegitimate child (Option D):

Also known as a bastard this describes a child born out of lawful wedlock or not within a competent time after the dissolution of marriage.

  • In this scenario, the child is born to a woman who was married, making this option incorrect.
  • Certain conditions can render a child illegitimate, including if the alleged father is under the age of puberty, physically incapable of fathering children, not sexually accessible to the mother at the time of conception, or has blood group incompatibility.
  • Legitimate Child: A child born during a lawful marriage or within 280 days after the marriage has been dissolved by divorce or death of the husband, as long as the mother remains unmarried.

Reference : Fabricated or induced illness: From "Munchausen by proxy" to child and family-oriented action - PubMed

questions.text: A person was brought from a railway track with dry dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and altered sensorium. What is the most likely poisoning?
questions.solution:
Datura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), dry mouth, tachycardia, slurred speech, hallucinations, confusion, and altered sensorium.

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Morphine (Option A): Morphine poisoning typically causes pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and sedation. Dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic features.

Cannabis (Option B): Cannabis intoxication may cause euphoria, altered sensorium, conjunctival injection (red eyes) and increased appetite but does not present with dry skin, dilated pupils, or the anticholinergic toxidrome seen in this case.

Alcohol (Option D): Alcohol intoxication commonly causes slurred speech and altered sensorium, but it does not result in dry skin or dilated pupils.

Learning Objective:

Toxins and Antidotes:

questions.text: A man wears female dresses and high heels and derives pleasure from doing so. He is not attracted to the same gender. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Transvestic fetishism involves individuals deriving sexual pleasure or emotional gratification from wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite gender. Importantly, this behavior is not associated with a desire to permanently transition to another gender or with same-gender attraction.

Voyeurism (Option B): Voyeurism involves obtaining sexual pleasure from secretly observing others who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities, which is unrelated to cross-dressing.

Sexual dysphoria (Option C): Sexual or gender dysphoria refers to a distressing incongruence between one's experienced gender and assigned sex, often leading to a desire to transition to another gender.

Gay orientation (Option D): Gay orientation refers to romantic or sexual attraction to individuals of the same gender.

Learning Objective:

Reference

  1. Treatment of Transvestic Fetishism With Fluoxetine: A Case Report - PMC

questions.text: What is the sequence of rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Nysten's Law

  • Rigor mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.
  • Order of Appearance:

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes

Rigor mortis

Rigor mortis (RM), or cadaveric rigidity, refers to the stiffening of muscles after death, resulting from biochemical changes within muscle cells due to ATP depletion.

Progression of Rigor Mortis:

The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases.

Rules of Progression

  1. Nysten's Rule
    • Rigor mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.
    • Order of Appearance:
      • Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes
    • Order of Disappearance:
      • Fingers and toes → Lower limbs → Abdomen → Upper limbs → Muscles of chest → Muscles of face → Lower jaw → Neck → Eyelid muscles → Myocardium
  2. Shapiro's Rule
    • Rigor mortis is a biochemical process that occurs simultaneously across all muscles, with visibility depending on muscle bulk.
  3. Rule of 12
    • Onset occurs at 60 minutes, peaks at 12 hours, remains for another 12 hours, and resolves completely thereafter.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is:
questions.solution:
Methods of Autopsy

1. Virchow's Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option C ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon's/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option A ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule's/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk.

Reference:

https://documents-cloud.cap.org/estore/pdf/PUB119_IntroAutopsy_Sample.pdf

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
• The above scenario is suggestive of Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.
  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.



Teichmann test (Option C): This test detects hemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

Acid phosphatase test (Option D): The Acid phosphatase test is used to detect the presence of prostatic fluid in sexual assault cases. It does not produce needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1187150/

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms described, including drowsiness, pain around the wound, bleeding, and blisters, are consistent with a viper bite.
  • Viper bites often lead to profuse bleeding due to the effects of venom-induced coagulopathy.

Cobra (Option B): Cobra bites are primarily neurotoxic, causing paralysis, respiratory distress, and potentially death if untreated. While cobras can cause pain and local swelling, they do not typically cause the extensive bleeding or blisters seen with viper bites. Cobras do not usually cause such local tissue necrosis and blistering.

Wasp bite (Option C): Wasp stings can cause pain, redness, and swelling at the sting site, but they typically do not lead to bleeding, drowsiness, or blisters. The symptoms described here are more consistent with a venomous bite from a snake rather than an insect sting.

Scorpion (Option D): While scorpion stings can cause pain, local swelling, and sometimes neurological symptoms (such as drowsiness), they typically do not cause blisters or profuse bleeding at the sting site. Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary edema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia,hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with hair loss, behavioral changes, lateral eyebrow loss, and nail changes. What is the type of poisoning in this case?
questions.solution:
The combination of alopecia, behavioral changes, lateral eyebrow loss, and nail findings strongly points to Thallium poisoning.


Arsenic (Option B): Arsenic poisoning can also cause Mees' lines, but it is not typically associated with alopecia or lateral eyebrow loss. Symptoms of arsenic toxicity include gastrointestinal distress, neuropathy, and hyperpigmentation or hypopigmentation of the skin.

Mercury (Option C): Mercury poisoning causes behavioral changes (e.g., irritability, tremors, and mood swings) and sometimes nail changes but is not associated with significant alopecia or lateral eyebrow loss.

Lead (Option D): Lead poisoning can cause behavioral changes, cognitive impairment, and lead lines (Burton's lines) on the gums but does not typically cause alopecia or loss of lateral eyebrows.

Reference: Long-term misdiagnosis and neurologic outcomes of thallium poisoning: A case report and literature review

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image.
questions.solution:
• The wound in the image points to an active defense wound where the victim has tried to grasp the weapon to prevent the attack and sustained injuries to the palm and on the fingers which would have been the case with a double-edged weapon.
  • Defence wounds are caused by the immediate and instinctive reaction of the victim to save himself from an attack and are usually seen on the extremities.
  • They are divided into two types:

Antemortem wound (Option B): They are characterized by signs of vital reactions such as bleeding, tissue bridging, clot formation, and signs of inflammation or healing. These features indicate that the injury occurred while the person was alive.

Postmortem wound (Option C): They lack vital reactions such as active bleeding or inflammation. They typically have clean, dry edges and no tissue bridging, as blood circulation ceases after death.

Hesitation cuts (Option D):


  • Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin.
  • These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon's hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?
questions.solution:
• The surgeon's decision to operate under the influence of alcohol constitutes criminal negligence, as it demonstrates reckless behavior leading to a fatal outcome.
  • This is likely to be prosecuted under Section 304A of the Indian Penal Code (BNS Section 106), which deals with causing death by a negligent act.

Civil Negligence Not Amounting to Criminal Negligence (Option B): Civil negligence involves a breach of duty leading to harm . The surgeon,s actions, being willful, surpass the threshold of civil negligence.

Therapeutic Misadventure (Option C): An unintended complication occurred during treatment, which was beyond the doctor's control. This does not apply, as the surgeon acted recklessly by operating while intoxicated.

Dichotomy (Option D): Dichotomy refers to the unethical practice of sharing fees between doctors or professionals and is unrelated to the situation described.

Learning Objective:



Reference

  1. IPC
  2. CORRESPONDENCE TABLE and COMPARISON SUMMARY OF THE BHARTATIYA NYAYA SANHITA, 2023 (BNS) to THE INDIAN PENAL CODE, 1860 (IPC)

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading questions are not allowed in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed during cross-examination because the opposing counsel aims to test the credibility and consistency of the witness. The nature of cross-examination permits more direct questioning.

Examination of Witness:

The below sequence is based on the Sec. 138 IEA.

Oath

↓

Chief examination

↓

Cross-examination

↓

Re-examination


Dying declaration (Option D): A dying declaration is the statement of a person who believes they are about to die. It is recorded as the person's own account, and leading questions are not allowed to avoid influencing their statement.

Reference

  1. https://bprd.nic.in/uploads/pdf/BNS.pdf

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.


Learning outcome:

Superfetation (Option A) refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant.

Suppositious child (Option C) refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own.

Atavism (Option D) refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations.

  • Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, by separate acts of coitus within a short period of time.
  • Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is only theoretically possible until the decidual space is obliterated by 12 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image of the marking nut is Bhilawanol-Semecarpus Anacardium

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning.
  • Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison.
  • Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes).
  • Seeds:
    • Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
    • They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air.
  • Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum. Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine.
    • Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes, delirium, coma, and potentially death.
    • Fatal dose: Approximately 5-10 g (5-8 seeds).
    • Fatal period: 12-24 hours.
  • Treatment:
    • Rinse the affected skin with soap and water.
    • Apply bland liniments.
    • Provide demulcent drinks and symptomatic treatment.
  • Medico-legal Aspects:
    • Criminal Use: The juice can be introduced vaginally as a form of punishment for infidelity or applied to the cervical os for illegal abortions.
    • Malingering: The juice can simulate conjunctivitis or falsely substantiate assault claims, as the lesions resemble bruises

Ricin (Option A) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

Abrin (Option C) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

Calotropin (Option D) is a cardiac glycoside found in plants of the Calotropis genus, such as Calotropis gigantea and Calotropis procera.

choices.text: Seen within first 12 hours of death
It occurs due to the accumulation of deoxygenated blood
It results due to bacterial activity
It is seen in case of lightning

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post-mortem change shown in the image given below?
questions.solution: The branching pattern along the blood vessels is typical of marbling, which occurs due to bacterial (Clostridium welchii) decomposition of hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin. This phenomenon usually appears 24 hours after death.

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.text: A female presents at 22 weeks of pregnancy due to rape. Which statement is correct regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, with the opinion of two doctors.

Indications for MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy):

  • Therapeutic:
    • When pregnancy endangers the woman’s life or health
    • e.g., cardiac disease, epilepsy, cancer, severe hyperemesis
  • Eugenic:
    • Risk of serious fetal abnormalities
    • e.g., anencephaly, rubella, teratogenic drug exposure
  • Socio-economic:
    • Unplanned pregnancy in poor socio-economic conditions
    • Failure of contraception
  • Humanitarian:
    • Pregnancy resulting from rape

Timing for MTP:

  • Up to 20 weeks: One doctor's opinion is required.
  • Beyond 20 weeks and less than 24 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman's life and pregnancy caused due to rape (Two doctor's decision). (Option C)
  • Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life.
  • Beyond 24 week: It is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board. (Option D ruled out)

Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required (Option A): Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother (Option B): While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

References:

  1. Legal Abortion Limit Raised up to 24 Weeks of Gestation for Substantial Foetal Anomalies or for Rape Victims: a Welcome Step for Women and Health Providers in India - PMC

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a body temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit strongly suggests a heat stroke, the symptom that is least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.

Heatstroke is a severe form of heat-related illness characterized by elevated body temperature.

Sweating is absent in heat stroke but present in exertional heat stroke

questions.text: A deceased male was brought to the morgue for a post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
When a tattoo is present on the skin of a deceased individual but cannot be found during the post-mortem examination, it is important to examine the regional lymph nodes. This is because tattoo pigments can be transported by the lymphatic system and accumulate in the adjacent lymph nodes.


Liver (Option B) is a vital organ involved in various metabolic functions, detoxification, and bile production. While the liver can be examined during a post-mortem examination for any signs of disease or abnormalities, it does not have a direct relationship with the presence or absence of a tattoo. Examining the liver would not reveal any information about the missing tattoo.

Arteries (Option C) are blood vessels responsible for carrying oxygenated blood from the heart to various parts of the body. While examining the arteries can provide information about the overall vascular health and potential causes of death, they are not directly related to the presence or disappearance of a tattoo. Examining the arteries would not provide any information about the missing tattoo.

Skin (Option D) is the outermost layer of the body and the site where tattoos are typically made. When investigating the absence of a tattoo, examining the skin itself is not the most appropriate approach.

questions.text: In relation to the punishment of perjury, which specific section of the IPC addresses this matter?
questions.solution: Punishment for False Evidence and Perjury (BNS 229/ IPC 193): This section deals with the punishment for giving false evidence (perjury) in any stage of a judicial proceeding or fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding.

questions.text: A child who is a victim under the POCSO Act is brought to the Department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image of the hand shows that all carpal bones are visible and the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not yet united with the shaft.

These findings indicate that the child's skeletal development is consistent with an age of approximately 13 years.



4 years (Option A) By the age of 4 years, the carpal bones in the hand would not be fully developed, and the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal would not be fused.

7 years (Option B) By the age of 7 years, most of the carpal bones would be visible on X-ray, but the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal would usually not be fused.

10 years (Option C) By the age of 10 years, the carpal bones would be well-developed and most of them would be fused. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal would not be fused by this age.

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.text: Frotteurism is characterized as _____________:
questions.solution: Reference: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532313/

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom?
questions.solution:
Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist. Scorpion venom contains compounds that can stimulate the release of catecholamines, such as norepinephrine. This can result in symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate.The treatment of choice for Indian red scorpion sting (Mesobuthus tamulus) is prazosin


Scorpion sting venom:

  • Physical properties: Venom is clear, colorless, proteinous toxalbumin, having haemolytic and neurotoxic effects.
  • Action: Venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals, leading to sympathetic overactivity.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary edema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia,hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

Treatment:

  • Limb is mobilised and pressure bandage is applied proximal to the site of sting.
  • The site may be incised and washed with ammonia or borax.
  • Prazosin therapy :Treatment of choice (1mg for adults, 500Ug for children) is given orally and then after every 3 hours till extremities are warm, dry, and peripheral veins are visible.
  • Scorpion antivenom (SAV) Specific antidote for scorpion venom.
  • Calcium gluconate 10 ml of 10% solution slow IV given for pain, cramps and edema.
  • Barbiturates given to sedate and control convulsion.
  • Atropine to prevent pulmonary edema.

Post-mortem findings:

  • Affected site is swollen
  • Stinger area showing ecchymosis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Myocardial infarction

Physostigmine (Option A) acts as an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, increasing the availability of acetylcholine in the body.

Norepinephrine (Option B) is a naturally occurring neurotransmitter and hormone that is involved in the sympathetic nervous system response.

Atropine (Option D) is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the action of acetylcholine in the body. It is commonly used to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine stimulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy?
questions.solution:
Saturated salt solution is commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Various methods of preserving viscera:

  1. Saturated salt solution
  2. Formalin fixation
  3. Freezing
  4. Alcohol preservation
  5. Formaldehyde solution
  6. Formalin-alcohol solution
  7. Frozen section
  8. Liquid nitrogen

Glycerin (Option A) is not commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. While it has some preservative properties, it is not as effective as saturated salt solution for maintaining tissue integrity and preventing decomposition.

Formalin (Option C) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses and can interfere with certain tests.

questions.text: Which is the first organ to putrefy?
questions.solution:
The brain is the first organ to putrefy after death due to its high metabolic rate and vulnerability to cell breakdown. Once oxygen supply is cut off, rapid decay occurs, aided by bacteria and enzymes.

Putrefaction sequence

Organs decompose at different rates based on their structure, vascularity, and exposure to air and bacteria. The general order of putrefaction is as follows:


  • First organs to decompose are the larynx and trachea due to their direct contact to air
  • The virgin uterus is the last organ to undergo putrefaction, while the gravid uterus, or uterus shortly after delivery, decomposes much more quickly.
  • Prostrate is the last organ to decompose in males. (Option D ruled out)
  • The overall last organ to decompose is bone/tooth.

questions.text:
Which of the following substances are antidotes for cyanide poisoning?
1. Amyl nitrate
2. Sodium nitrate
3. Sodium thiosulphate
4. Benzyl thiocyanate
questions.solution:
• Amyl nitrate : Amyl nitrate induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide ions to form cyanomethemoglobin, reducing cyanide's availability to inhibit cytochrome oxidase.
  • Sodium nitrate : Sodium nitrate also induces methemoglobinemia, complementing the action of amyl nitrate in detoxifying cyanide.
  • Sodium thiosulphate : Sodium thiosulphate acts as a sulfur donor, converting cyanide into the less toxic thiocyanate via the enzyme rhodanese.
  • Benzyl thiocyanate : Benzyl thiocyanate is not a recognized antidote for cyanide poisoning and has no established role in its treatment.

Learning Objective:

questions.text:
What is the correct order of opening cavities in case of a fetal autopsy:

A. Head
B. Thorax
C. Abdomen
questions.solution:
• In a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of cavity opening is critical to determine if the fetus was stillborn or live-born.
  • The following is the reasoning behind the order:
    • Head: The cranial cavity is opened first to assess for intracranial hemorrhage or brain abnormalities without disturbing other cavities.
    • Abdomen is opened second to allow palpation of the diaphragm before the thoracic cavity is opened. This helps determine its position and shape, which can indicate whether the lungs were inflated-an important clue to whether the fetus ever breathed.
    • Thorax is opened last, as doing so prematurely may disturb the diaphragm or create artificial changes in intrathoracic pressure.

Learning Objective:




Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/

questions.text: Marshall's triad (punctate lacerations, bruises, and abrasions) is seen in which type of blast injury?
questions.solution:
Secondary blast injuries are Caused by flying debris and shrapnel propelled by the blast. This results in Marshall's triad: punctate lacerations, bruises, and abrasions, characteristic of injuries from high-velocity fragments.

Blast Injury: Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, leading to sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute grievous hurt under Section 320 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)?
questions.solution:
BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous:

  1. Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury). (Option A ruled out)
  2. Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  3. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear. (Option C ruled out)
  4. Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints
  5. Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth. (Option B ruled out)
  8. Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 20 days, in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine.

Reference:

  1. https://www.mha.gov.in/sites/default/files/250883_english_01042024.pdf
  2. https://bprd.nic.in/uploads/pdf/COMPARISON%20SUMMARY%20BNS%20to%20IPC%20.pdf

questions.text: All of the following are used in the identification of a dead body except?
questions.solution:
Nails are not a primary tool for identification. While they may occasionally provide DNA, their utility is limited compared to teeth and blood and muscle.


Teeth (Option A): Teeth are highly reliable for forensic identification due to their resistance to decomposition and the ability to compare dental records. They can also be a source of DNA for profiling.

Blood (Option B): Blood is a primary biological material used for DNA analysis, providing a unique genetic fingerprint for identifying the deceased.

Muscle (Option D): Muscle tissue, while less durable, can be used for DNA extraction if preserved adequately. It serves as an auxiliary source for identification when other tissues are unavailable.

Learning Objective:


Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19083867/

choices.text: No mud and vegetation in the respiratory tract

questions.text: A girl was found deceased in a lake, and her body was retrieved. Which of the following is false regarding ante-mortem drowning?
questions.solution:
• In ante-mortem drowning, mud, vegetation, or other debris from the drowning medium may be aspirated into the respiratory tract during the victim's struggle to breathe.
  • The presence of these elements can confirm ante-mortem drowning.

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs: Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged, Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf's spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Water in the stomach (Option A): In cases of ante-mortem drowning, water may be swallowed and found in the stomach as a result of reflexive actions during the drowning process.

Froth on nose and mouth (Option B): Froth is a characteristic feature of ante-mortem drowning, caused by the mixing of water, air, and mucus during respiratory efforts.

Cadaveric spasm in hand muscle (Option D): Cadaveric spasm, particularly in the hand muscles (e.g., tightly holding grass or weeds), is often seen in drowning cases as a sign of intense physical and emotional struggle before death.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: Identify the given plant based on its features.
questions.solution:
The above image matches the characteristics of Argemone Mexicana, known for its yellow flowers and toxic properties.

  • Argemone Mexicana:
    • Commonly known as prickly poppy.
    • The plant is characterized by its yellow flowers, prickly leaves, and a milky sap.
    • It is toxic due to alkaloids such as sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine, which can cause health issues like epidemic dropsy.

Datura Alba (Option A): Known as white datura, it has white trumpet-shaped flowers and is associated with anticholinergic toxicity.


Nerium Odorum (Option C): Known as oleander, it has pink or white flowers and contains cardiac glycosides causing poisoning.


Papaver Somniferum (Option D): Commonly known as the opium poppy, it produces latex rich in alkaloids like morphine and codeine.

questions.text: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?
questions.solution:
Atropa belladonna, also known as "Deadly Nightshade," contains tropane alkaloids (atropine, scopolamine). While it affects the autonomic nervous system (causing tachycardia, dry mouth, and dilated pupils), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison.

Some common cardiac poisons include:

  • Aconite (Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox)
  • Nicotine (Nicotiana tabacum)
  • Digitalis (Digitalis purpurea)
  • Oleander (Cerbera thevetia, Cerbera odorum)
  • Quinine

Aconite (Option A):

  • Aconite is cardiac poison derived from the Aconitum plant.
  • It causes arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest by altering sodium channel function.

Cerbera thevetia (Option B): Commonly known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that interfere with the sodium-potassium ATPase pump.

Nicotiana tabacum (Option C): Tobacco contains nicotine, which can act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and cause tachycardia or bradycardia depending on the dose.

questions.text: Under which doctrine is the doctor not responsible when a patient with life-threatening injuries arrives at the casualty without time for consent and the doctor initiates life-saving procedures with the utmost care, but unfortunately, the patient still succumbs to death?
questions.solution:
If a patient with life-threatening injuries is brought to the emergency department and dies despite proper care, the doctor is not held responsible under the Doctrine of anticipation, provided all actions were done competently and ethically.

Doctrine of anticipation (also known as implied consent in emergencies): This legal and ethical doctrine allows a doctor to initiate life-saving treatment without formal consent when:

  • The patient is unconscious or unable to give consent.
  • The delay in treatment to obtain consent would risk the patient's life.
  • The treatment is in the patient's best interest and carried out with due care and skill.

Explanation for other options:

Res ipsa loquitur (Option B): A legal doctrine meaning "the thing speaks for itself", used in cases of obvious negligence, not applicable here.

Doctrine of extended consent (Option C): Refers to permission to perform additional procedures during a planned surgery if unexpected issues arise. Not applicable to emergencies without prior consent.

Doctrine of Conjugated Consent (Option D): Not a recognised legal or medical doctrine; A distractor.

Reference:

http://radiology.con.mk/consent/2/extension_doctrine.html?i=1

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
• Nigella sativa (black seed) is a medicinal plant from the Ranunculaceae family, widely used in traditional medicines like Unani, Ayurveda, and Tibb-e-Nabwi.
  • These are small, black, angular seeds commonly known as black cumin or kalonji, used in cooking and traditional medicine.
  • Therapeutic Uses: It has various health benefits, including anti-hypertensive, anti-diabetic, anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hepatoprotective properties.
  • Key Component: The active compound, thymoquinone, in the oil and seeds, is responsible for most of its therapeutic effects.
  • Common Uses: It is used to treat conditions like bronchitis, asthma, diarrhea, rheumatism, and skin disorders, and also as a digestive aid, appetite stimulant, and immune booster.
  • Cultural Significance: Considered a "miracle herb," it is highly regarded in Islamic medicine, where it is believed to cure all diseases except death.

Tropicana canna (Option A): The seeds are large, spherical, and hard, typically used as beads or ornaments. They do not resemble the smaller, black, and shiny seeds of Nigella sativa.


Datura seeds (Option C): Datura seeds are flat, kidney-shaped, and brownish-yellow, distinct from the black seeds of Nigella sativa.


Opium seeds (Option D): Also known as poppy seeds, they are small, round, and greyish-blue, distinctly different in color and texture from Nigella sativa seeds.


Reference:

A review on therapeutic potential of Nigella sativa: A miracle herb - PMC

Black Seed: Benefits, Nutrition, Uses & Health Insights

questions.text: Which of the following defines rape?
questions.solution:
Rape definition and conditions

Section 375 IPC (BNS 63) defines rape:

  1. a) Penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  2. b) Inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  3. c) Manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  4. d) Applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:
    1. Against her will
    2. Without her consent
    3. With her consent, only because she or someone she cares about is threatened with harm or death.
    4. With her consent, she mistakenly believes the man is her lawful husband when the man knows that he is not her husband.
    5. With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, she cannot understand the nature or consequences due to intoxication, mental incapacity, or being drugged.
    6. With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
    7. When she is unable to communicate consent.

Exceptions:

  • A medical procedure or intervention shall not constitute rape.
  • Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under eighteen years of age, is not rape.

Note: Even if a girl gives consent below 18 years, it is known as statutory rape.

376 IPC (Option B) prescribes the punishment for rape. It outlines the penalties for committing rape, including rigorous imprisonment and fines, with more severe punishments for aggravated circumstances.

377 IPC (Option C) pertains to unnatural offenses, criminalizing sexual acts "against the order of nature" (a historically controversial provision, partially decriminalized for consensual same-sex relations in 2018).

498(A) IPC (Option D) addresses cruelty by husband or relatives of the husband towards a woman. This includes harassment, physical abuse, and mental torture, often related to dowry demands.

Reference: Section 63

questions.text:
During the visit to the outpatient department, a female patient aged 18 years was examined. The genital examination disclosed the following observations. These observations suggest:
1. Labia majora - separated
2. Labia minora - flabby
3. Fourchette tear present
4. Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen
questions.solution:
Premenstrual stage (Option C) genitalia are underdeveloped, with thick labia majora, small labia minora, and a firm hymen admitting only small instruments. The patient's findings suggest a post-pubertal state, not a premenstrual stage.

Molestation (Option D) may involve bruises, hymenal tears, and disrupted commissures. While a fourchette tear is present, the intact hymen and absence of other trauma make this less likely.

Reference:

  1. Hymen
  2. Hymen & Virginity
